messageBody:
At 05:18 PM 6/11/2001 -0400, you wrote:
Thanks for the example in design issues... but that isn't what I was after.
I should have been more clear, and I will be next time.

Ok. Point well taken. back to the main track.

 I wanted to point out the potential flaws of design and
testing that could otherwise be missed when you put tests in the same
package as production code.  The production code should be tested in the
same fashion it would be used by a client.  A test is a client in some
degree.  In most cases clients exist outside of the package.
[..snip]
Thus,
I conclude, that testing the public interfaces of ALL objects (the key being
ALL) should prove sufficient, thus not needing the tests to reside in the
same package as their associated production code objects.  Of course, there
are exceptions... we have ways around those.

In an ideal world, you're right. Testing *all* the public methods should give you complete functional coverage.
However:
1. You might want to put more stress on some classes and less on others. In this case, you might want to test more then the public methods of critical-path components, and less of the peripherals.
2. You might want to access non-public methods in your setUp / tearDown.
3. Sometimes the tested class needs a sophisticated context in runtime (EJB / Servlet). In this case, you might want to short circuit it in testing by calling protected / default access methods that would be called by the public interface in production mode.

True, you might call all these "exceptions". True, they deter from the pure model. Still, they are common, and are easily resolved by placing tests in the same package. On the other hand, I don't see the actual harm of doing so.

B.t.w., the right access mode for "accessible in package only" is "default". "protected" makes it accessible to both package members and subclassses.
